en: Interview with Walt McFalls, resident of Gatlinburg. McFalls recounts the day of the fire and the efforts he made to evacuate safely. He also discusses the visible changes over time of the forest recovering during the years following. This is a representative quote from the interview: "It got so hot around [my niece's] house that the vinyl siding melted and ran down the house, but the house never caught on fire."
Individuals (tourists or locals) directly affected by the fire

Interview with Walt McFalls, resident of Gatlinburg. McFalls recounts the day of the fire and the efforts he made to evacuate safely. He also discusses the visible changes over time of the forest recovering during the years following. This is a representative quote from the interview: "It got so hot around [my niece's] house that the vinyl siding melted and ran down the house, but the house never caught on fire."

Could you share with us why you wanted to participate in the project? What is your background in the area?
Can you tell us about how long you've been in the area?
Do you have any other ties to the community?
What part of town did you live in before the fire?
Can you tell us about the days leading up to the fire?
What was it like walking through the woods to get back to your home?
Was there any smoke damage to your home?
Do you remember anything about the winds during that time?
You said that there was no kind of official warning that day?
Had there been any smoke leading up to those days?
Do you remember how long until power was turned back on?
Can you talk more about the evacuation process? Was there traffic or other concerns?
About what time did you evacuate that day?
What was the night you spent in the motel like?
You had mentioned before the interview, that you were an avid hiker?
Can you tell us what off trail hiking is?
What were some of the changes immediately after the fire and later?
What have you noticed growing on the trails?
Are invasive species coming back faster?
Is there anything else you would like to add?
Were there local communities also providing relief?
Are there signs that people or the City are better prepared now?

seo.title: Interview with Walt McFalls, 2019-12-14 - Rising From the Ashes Oral Histories

He also discusses the visible changes over time of the forest recovering during the years following. This is a representative quote from the interview: "It got so hot around [my niece's] house that the vinyl siding melted and ran down the house, but the house never caught on fire."
